unnormalised: Okay, so someone asked about the best way to find a flat in Mumbai. It's honestly a jungle out here, especially if you're new to the city. I've been living in Mumbai for 5+ years now, so I've been through the ringer, haha.
normalised: Okay, so someone asked about the best way to find a flat in Mumbai. It's honestly a jungle out here, especially if you're new to the city. I've been living in Mumbai for five plus years now, so I've been through the ringer, ha ha.

unnormalised: First off, decide where you want to live. Mumbai is HUGE. Do you want to be near your office? Near the sea? Or in a quieter suburb? Areas like Bandra (W) and Juhu are fancy, but expensive. Places like Andheri (E) and Borivali are more affordable, but the commute might be a pain. Think about that 1st! My first place was at 201, Sai Apartment, Lokhandwala Complex, Andheri (W), 400053. Good memories, but the traffic...oof.
normalised: First off, decide where you want to live. Mumbai is huge. Do you want to be near your office? Near the sea? Or in a quieter suburb? Areas like Bandra (W) and Juhu are fancy, but expensive. Places like Andheri (E) and Borivali are more affordable, but the commute might be a pain. Think about that first! My first place was at two hundred and one, Sai Apartment, Lokhandwala Complex, Andheri (W), four hundred thousand and fifty three. Good memories, but the traffic...oof.

unnormalised: Next, start your search online. Websites like NoBroker, Magicbricks, and 99acres are good starting points. Filter by your budget, location, and requirements (1 BHK, 2 BHK, etc.). Don't trust everything you see online though, the photos can be misleading. Always visit the place in person before you commit! One friend of mine got stuck with a "sea-facing" apartment that was actually 5 km from the beach!
normalised: Next, start your search online. Websites like NoBroker, Magicbricks, and ninety nine acres are good starting points. Filter by your budget, location, and requirements (one B-H-K, two B-H-K, etcetera). Don't trust everything you see online though, the photos can be misleading. Always visit the place in person before you commit! One friend of mine got stuck with a "sea-facing" apartment that was actually five kilometer from the beach!

unnormalised: When you visit, check EVERYTHING. Is the water pressure good? Are there any leaks? Is the building well-maintained? Talk to the neighbours if you can – they'll give you the real scoop. Also, confirm the address properly. I saw one listing for "Flat no. 7, B wing, XYZ Residency, Powai, 400076" but the actual flat number was 707!
normalised: When you visit, check everything. Is the water pressure good? Are there any leaks? Is the building well-maintained? Talk to the neighbors if you can – they'll give you the real scoop. Also, confirm the address properly. I saw one listing for "Flat number seven, B wing, X-Y-Z Residency, Powai, four hundred thousand and seventy six" but the actual flat number was seven hundred and seven!

unnormalised: Finally, be prepared to negotiate. Landlords in Mumbai can be tough! Don't be afraid to bargain on the rent or the deposit. And get EVERYTHING in writing. A proper rental agreement is essential. It'll save you a lot of headaches later on. Good luck finding your dream flat! Maybe you'll end up near me at C-10, Dreamland society, Goregaon (E), 400063 ;)
